image.altText: A woman with a blue shirt wearing a white jacket smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: In estimates hearings today, a Canberra Institute of Technology official confirmed former chief executive Leanne Cover received the lump sum as well as being paid her annual salary for two years while on leave.

title.children: 'Corrupt' former CIT CEO was paid almost half a million dollars upon resigning, official reveals

image.altText: Grindr

props.synopsis: ACT police believe the three alleged homophobic assaults are linked and targeted, with the most recent incident allegedly occurring in the early hours of Saturday July 20, less than two hours after the second reported attack outside the same vacant Red Hill residence.

title.children: Third alleged homophobic attack in Canberra happened only hours after another, police say

image.altText: Large plastic bags with Australian Federal Police stickers containing medication bags

props.synopsis: A 33-year-old Chinese national is arrested after police seized an estimated $5 million worth of steroids and other drugs they allege were being sold by mail order.

title.children: ACT police seize 55,000 vials and 156,000 tablets of steroids and other drugs allegedly sold through the mail

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian looking serious.

props.synopsis: The former NSW premier has failed to overturn a finding of serious corrupt conduct after challenging a report by the corruption watchdog in the state's highest civil court.

title.children: 'I always worked my hardest': Gladys Berejiklian fails to overturn ICAC corruption findings

image.altText: Big sign saying Australian National University.

props.synopsis: The Australian National University says it is "deeply sorry" for the error that saw 2,290 former and current casual staff miss payments totalling about $2 million during the past 11 years, and had self-reported to the Fair Work Ombudsman.

title.children: More than 2,000 casual Australian National University staff underpaid over 11 years due to timesheet error

image.altText: Bruce Lehrman leaves the Federal Court of Australia in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer tells the Federal Court the former Liberal staffer wants to delay paying the $2 million he owes to Network Ten, pending a possible appeal against the ruling in his failed defamation case.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann seeking to delay paying $2 million he owes to Network Ten, Federal Court told

image.altText: A prohibition notice is stuck to the closed doors of Central Cafe in Gungahlin.

props.synopsis: The then 15-year-old had been working at a Canberra cafe when she was hospitalised with a salmonella infection.

title.children: Teenage kitchen hand awarded $65,000 after contracting salmonella at work

image.altText: An empty rail station with a high-speed train in the foreground

props.synopsis: The attacks have been characterised as "malicious" by train operator SCNF.

title.children: France's high-speed rail network disrupted by arson attacks hours before Olympics ceremony

image.altText: Strobe lights surround an illuminated Eiffel Tower at night

props.synopsis: The opening ceremony for the 2024 Olympic Games, held almost entirely along Paris's River Seine, promises to be the most spectacular ever attempted — but it brings with it many complications and immeasurable risk.

title.children: Inside the Paris opening ceremony — the most spectacular and riskiest ever attempted

image.altText: Donald Trump is shielded by secret service as blood spreads from an injury on his ear

props.synopsis: Much about the shooter's motives, methods and how he was allowed to get so close to former US president Donald Trump during a campaign rally in Pennsylvania on July 13 remain a mystery.

title.children: A bullet or shrapnel? Here's what we know almost two weeks after the attempted assassination of Donald Trump

image.altText: US Senator Kamala Harris smiles widely as she walks ahead of three other people.

props.synopsis: As Joe Biden starts his long goodbye with a televised address from the Oval Office, Donald Trump and his likely rival in November's presidential election, Kamala Harris, have been trading blows as a recast race for the White House begins.

title.children: As Biden pledges to 'pass the torch', his VP is sharpening her attacks on Trump

image.altText: Older woman with grey hair holding a colourful hand knitted doll.

props.synopsis: Carolyn Crawford's addiction to the pokies was so bad she used to hear their bells while lying in bed at night. She says the only way to save chronic gamblers from jail is through a system of "gambling courts".

title.children: She'd never even had a parking fine, but Carolyn's pokies addiction landed her in jail at 64

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu and Kamala Harris shake hands in front of US and Israel flags.

props.synopsis: The US vice-president has met with Israel's prime minister in what she describes as "frank" talks on the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

title.children: 'I will not be silent': Harris presses Netanyahu over humanitarian situation in Gaza

image.altText: Tourists climb up a stretch of the Badaling Great Wall of China on the outskirts of Beijing

props.synopsis: Several Asian countries have eased rules or removed fees for Australian visitors. Find out where and what it means for your next holiday or business trip.

title.children: These Asian nations want more tourists — here's how they're making it cheaper and easier for Australians

image.altText: Bev Priestman

props.synopsis: Canada's women's soccer coach is removed from her position as more claims emerge of drones being used to spy on opponents.

title.children: Canadian soccer coach sent home from Paris as additional claims of drone spying emerge

image.altText: Rohan Taylor speaks at a media conference ahead of the Paris Olympics.

props.synopsis: Swimming Australia head coach Rohan Taylor says coach Michael Palfrey will face "consequences" for his inflammatory comments when the Paris Games finish.

title.children: 'Un-Australian' swimming coach to face consequences over Korea comments, but only after Paris Olympics

image.altText: Patty Mills during a Boomers warm up

props.synopsis: Through controversial selection, an aggressive game style and brash confidence, the Boomers are putting all their chips in at the Paris Olympics — and in what might be the most competitive Games ever, it's gold or bust for the Aussies.

title.children: Gold vibes only — the Boomers have the band back together, and aren't settling for bronze

image.altText: An old photograph and sketch of a man in a photo collage

props.synopsis: Mexican drug lord Ismael "El Mayo" Zambada and the son of his former partner, Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, were arrested in Texas.

title.children: Mexican drug lord 'El Mayo' and El Chapo's son arrested in Texas

image.altText: A police officer standing near a wall with the words Zionism is Facism painted on.

props.synopsis: Federal Labor MP Josh Burns thanks police for charging a 17- and 18-year-old pair for allegedly anti-Semitic vandalism of his Melbourne office.

title.children: Two teenagers charged over a vandalism attack at federal MP Josh Burns's office

image.altText: Oscar Piastri raises a bottle of wine in victory, holding a winners's trophy in his other arm

props.synopsis: Oscar Piastri comes into this weekend's Formula 1 grand prix weekend in a new position — as a grand prix winner.

title.children: Fresh off his history-making F1 win, Piastri returns to his 'favourite track' ready to challenge for another victory

image.altText: a small white modular home

props.synopsis: Young adults are increasingly drawing on the "bank of mum and dad" no matter what their parents' income and for far more than a housing deposit, researchers have found.

title.children: What happens when the 'bank of mum and dad' becomes a housing safety net?

image.altText: Premier Steven Miles and Commissioner Steve Gollschewski

props.synopsis: Queensland's police commissioner says taking two private jets to regional cities for a series of announcements in April with the premier and other MPs cost taxpayers about $167,000.

title.children: Two private jets for premier and new top cop cost Queensland taxpayers $167,000

image.altText: AFL player Cyril Rioli smiling, holding the AFL Premiership Cup, on the parade lap, after winning the grand final

props.synopsis: Rioli has lodged a racism claim in the Federal Court on behalf of his wife and other former First Nations players.

title.children: Former AFL premiership star Cyril Rioli launches fresh court challenge against Hawthorn Football Club over alleged racism

image.altText: A man smiling agianst a backgrop of water, wearing sunglasses in the sunny glare.

props.synopsis: The Australian embassy is understood to be involved in bringing the body of Liam Ryan back to Australia.

title.children: Perth family pay tribute to 'beautiful, gifted' man killed while on Thai holiday

image.altText: Two woman hold a sign that says Don't torch journalism.

props.synopsis: Journalists at Nine newspapers have begun a five-day strike after rejecting a pay offer from management ahead of the Paris Olympics opening ceremony.

title.children: Nine media executives 'very confident' in Olympics coverage despite five-day strike

image.altText: A sinking oil tanker.

props.synopsis: Efforts are underway to clean up an oil spill that could reach the Philippines capital following the sinking of a tanker in rough seas.

title.children: Typhoon Gaemi hits China after sinking ships and causing an oil spill that threatens Philippines capital

image.altText: Monkeypox view under the microscope

props.synopsis: Australia is experiencing a resurgence of mpox, prompting alerts from state health departments as clusters of the virus continue to grow.

title.children: Calls to limit sexual partners as mpox makes a resurgence in Australia

image.altText: A soccer player wearing white and black holds her arms in the air while another player in yellow looks sad behind her

props.synopsis: Twenty-four years ago, the Matildas lost to Germany 3-0 in their opening Olympics group game. Will history continue to repeat itself in Paris?

title.children: Matildas haunted by history in Olympic loss to Germany

image.altText: Close-up of two hands holding a mobile phone with a blurred social media platform on screen

props.synopsis: Meta announces about 63,000 Instagram accounts in Nigeria have been taken down after attempting to engage in financial sextortion schemes mostly targeting at men.

title.children: Meta removes 63,000 Instagram accounts linked to Nigerian sextortion scams

image.altText: Two men walking outside of court

props.synopsis: Two teenagers who wanted to date each other were instead forced by relatives to marry, a Perth court hears.

title.children: Trio accused of forcing teens into arranged marriage 'for cultural reasons'

image.altText: A drill rig working in the outback with red dirt.

props.synopsis: One of the world's biggest drilling companies has been fined $385,000 after a worker was seriously injured while reassembling a drill rig at a remote mineral exploration camp in Western Australia three years ago.

title.children: Drilling company fined $385k after rig worker's head crushed

image.altText: Stephen Edwards with parents David and Nelda

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian coroner is scathing about the testimony of a man who, when a practising doctor, administered drugs which the court has found brought about the death of his mother, just 48 hours after his father died.

title.children: Coroner finds man caused mother's death with cocktail of drugs, 48 hours after father died

image.altText: A Windows PC shwing a "Blue Screen of Death" error.

props.synopsis: Virtual gift cards offered by cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike to those who aided customers through the global IT outage have been blocked and flagged for potential fraud by Uber.

title.children: CrowdStrike issued $10 'thank you' vouchers. They were then blocked for potential fraud

image.altText: An illustration of a very tall man with an 18th century tricorne hat on. Other people come up to his elbows in height

props.synopsis: Known as the Irish Giant, Charles Byrne's dying wish was to be buried at sea to avoid being dissected and displayed after he died. But he was betrayed and centuries later the debate over where his remains should rest continues.

title.children: The 'Irish Giant' was petrified of becoming a surgeon's plaything. A betrayal saw his worst fears come true
